temporal_analysis.chronology_significance: Temple founded during Crusader States military crisis

institutional_emergence.documented_crisis: Only 300 knights in Baldwin I's service, high mortality
institutional_emergence.pilgrim_danger: Muslim ambushes between Jaffa and Jerusalem (Saewulf, Daniel of Kiev)

islamic_influence_rejection.ribat_hypothesis: Rejected - no direct evidence of borrowing
islamic_influence_rejection.structural_differences: Ribat = temporary volunteers vs. Templars = permanent vows
islamic_influence_rejection.functional_differences: Ribat = frontier fortress, Templars = Jerusalem-based pilgrim protection
islamic_influence_rejection.temporal_evidence: No military ribats on crusader borders during early 12th century

christian_development_trajectory.knighthood_transformation: militia Christi redefined from monastic to warrior
christian_development_trajectory.legal_basis: Lay brothers (fratres laici) not clerics, thus not bound by canonical weapons prohibition

theological_legitimization.bernard_defense: De laude novae militiae justifies killing infidels for Christ
theological_legitimization.penitential_warfare: Fighting can be imposed as penance
theological_legitimization.defensive_to_offensive: Defense of Church expanded to recovery of lost territories

institutional_hybridity.monastic_adoption: Rules borrowed from Benedictine and Cistercian traditions
institutional_hybridity.military_integration: Combat added without breaking religious framework
institutional_hybridity.authority_anchoring: Biblical prophecies cited to legitimize innovation
